title: 109_s2695
content: The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 aims to make research findings funded by the government accessible to the public through the internet. This Act emphasizes the importance of sharing research to advance science and benefit society. The term "Federal agency" in this Act refers to an Executive agency defined under section 105 of title 5, United States Code. Each Federal agency with extramural research expenditures over $100,000,000 must develop a Federal research public access policy within a year of this Act. The policy requires authors to submit an electronic version of their final manuscript of research papers funded by the Federal Government to the agency for publication in peer-reviewed journals. The Federal research public access policy mandates authors to submit their final manuscripts of federally funded research papers for publication in peer-reviewed journals. This includes incorporating changes from peer review, replacing manuscripts with published versions if approved by the publisher, and providing free online access within 6 months of publication. The Federal research public access policy requires the submission of final manuscripts of federally funded research papers for publication in peer-reviewed journals, with free online access within 6 months. Additionally, it mandates the creation of an online bibliography linking to free full-text papers and the long-term preservation of published research findings in a digital repository maintained by the Federal agency. The Federal research public access policy mandates free public access, interoperability, and long-term preservation of research works. It applies to researchers employed or funded by the Federal agency, requiring public domain works to be marked as such and made immediately available. The Federal research public access policy requires the creation and reservation of a Government license for final manuscripts for Federal purposes. Exclusions include laboratory notes, preliminary data analyses, and classified research. The Federal research public access policy mandates the creation of a Government license for final manuscripts for Federal purposes, excluding laboratory notes, preliminary data analyses, and classified research. The Act does not impact rights under title 17 or 35, United States Code. Federal agencies must submit a report annually by October 1. Each Federal agency must submit a report on the Federal research public access policy to the Senate and House committees, as well as any other relevant congressional committee. The report should assess the effectiveness of the policy in providing public access. The Federal agency must submit a report on the research public access policy to Congress, evaluating its effectiveness in providing free online access to federally funded research papers. The report should include lists of published papers, papers available through the policy, and timeframes for public availability. The Federal agency is required to make the statement and lists of papers available to the public on its website.
